HL7 Standard.summary: This Implementation Guide, QI-Core, is fundamentally based on FHIR and extends US Core to standardize clinical data representation for quality improvement. It does not directly involve HL7 v2 or v3 messaging, nor does it focus on CDA document exchange. While it acknowledges and maps to models like QDM (which has roots in v3), its core approach is entirely FHIR-centric. The IG does show some cross-paradigm awareness by mapping to QDM and mentioning vMR, but this is not a central aspect of its design.

Geographic Scope.summary: The QI-Core Implementation Guide explicitly states it is designed for use within the US Realm and builds upon US Core profiles. This indicates a clear national scope focused on the United States.

Domain Focus.summary: The QI-Core Implementation Guide primarily focuses on standardizing the representation of clinical data for quality measurement and clinical decision support within the US Realm. It leverages FHIR R4 and US Core to define profiles and extensions that facilitate interoperability in quality improvement applications. While it touches upon care planning and workflow, its core purpose revolves around clinical data and its use in quality reporting.

Implementers.summary: The QI-Core IG focuses on standardizing clinical data representation for quality measurement and clinical decision support within the US Realm. It primarily targets EHR systems and CDS systems, requiring them to implement its profiles and extensions. Other systems like lab, pharmacy, and research platforms have important but more specific roles in supporting quality improvement data. Payer and public health systems have minimal direct involvement in implementing the core data representation aspects of this IG.

Users & Stakeholders.summary: The QI-Core Implementation Guide primarily serves the needs of developers building quality measurement and clinical decision support systems. Clinical Care Teams and Research Organizations are also key users, as they provide and utilize the data standardized by this IG. Payers and Public Health Agencies have a significant interest in the outcomes of quality improvement initiatives, while Government Agencies are involved in setting standards and regulations related to quality reporting. Patients and Healthcare Administrators have a less direct but still relevant role.
